p: Light attenuation in forests can result in <10% sunlight reaching understory trees [ 111], yet eastern redcedars still survive [ 52]. It is likely that the longer growing season for these evergreen trees allows them to outcompete deciduous trees in the winter despite the lower light intensities [ 52]. I note that, although eastern redcedars are evergreen, they stop growing (even in the greenhouse in Ohio) over mid-winter when the mean low temperatures in January and February in neighboring Chardon are -9.8°C and -9.4°C, respectively.
